description: Returns the character at the specified index. Allows for positive and negative integers, where negative integers count back from the last character of the string.

parameters.description: The index of the character to be returned. Positive integers start from the beginning of the string, while negative integers start from the end.

return.value: The character at the specified index or undefined if the index is out of bounds.

use_cases.title: Accessing the first character
use_cases.code:
const str = 'Hello World!';
console.log(str.at(0));
use_cases.explanation: This example shows how to use `at()` to access the first character of a string. It outputs 'H'.

use_cases.title: Accessing the last character with a negative index
use_cases.code:
const str = 'Hello World!';
console.log(str.at(-1));
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates accessing the last character of a string by using a negative index with `at()`, which outputs '!'.

use_cases.title: Comparing `at()` with traditional indexing
use_cases.code:
const str = 'Hello World!';
console.log(`at(): ${str.at(-2)}, traditional: ${str[str.length - 2]}`);
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates the convenience of using `at()` for accessing characters from the end of a string, compared to the more cumbersome traditional bracket notation.

description: Returns the character at the specified index (position) in a string.

parameters.description: Optional. The index (position) of the character. Default = 0.

return.value: The character at the specified index.

use_cases.title: Accessing a specific character
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the character at index 4 ('o') from the sentence. This demonstrates how to use charAt() to access a specific character in a string based on its index.

use_cases.title: Handling out-of-range index
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to access a character at an index that exceeds the string's length, resulting in an empty string. This highlights charAt()'s behavior when the specified index is out of range.

use_cases.title: Default to first character
use_cases.explanation: Accesses the first character of the string by not specifying an index, which defaults to 0. This illustrates that charAt() will return the first character if the index parameter is omitted or undefined.

use_cases.title: Using charAt in a loop
use_cases.explanation: Loops through each character of the string, printing one character at a time. This use case shows how charAt() can be effectively used within a loop to process or examine each character of a string individually.

use_cases.title: Comparing charAt with direct access
use_cases.explanation: Compares accessing a character using charAt() with direct bracket notation. Both methods retrieve the character at the specified index, but charAt() provides a safer approach by returning an empty string for out-of-range indexes, unlike direct access which returns undefined.

description: Returns the Unicode of the character at the specified index in a string.

parameters.description: Optional. A number representing the index (position) of a character. Default value = 0.

return.value: The Unicode of the character at the specified index.

use_cases.title: Get character code
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the Unicode character code (UTF-16) of the character at index 7 ('W') from the sentence. This demonstrates how to use charCodeAt() to access the character code at a specific position in a string.

use_cases.title: Handling out-of-range index
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to access the character code at an index that exceeds the string's length, resulting in NaN. This highlights charCodeAt()'s behavior when the specified index is out of the valid range.

use_cases.title: Comparing characters
use_cases.explanation: Compares the character codes of 'a' and 'b' to determine their lexicographical order. This use case shows how charCodeAt() can be used for comparing characters based on their Unicode values.

use_cases.title: Detecting character type
use_cases.explanation: Uses charCodeAt() to check if a character is a digit by comparing its character code with the Unicode ranges for digit characters ('0'-'9'). This illustrates charCodeAt()'s utility in type detection and validation of character data.

use_cases.title: Encoding a string
use_cases.explanation: Encodes a string into a sequence of Unicode values. By mapping each character to its charCodeAt() value and joining them, this example demonstrates a simple way to encode textual data for processing or transmission.

description: Returns a non-negative integer that is the Unicode code point value of the character at the specified position in the string.

parameters.description: The position of an element in the string for which the Unicode code point is returned. If `position` is not a number, it is treated as `0`.

return.value: The Unicode code point value of the character at the specified position. Returns `undefined` if the position is out of bounds.

use_cases.title: Getting the code point of a character
use_cases.code:
const str = 'ð ®·';
console.log(str.codePointAt(0));
use_cases.explanation: This example demonstrates getting the Unicode code point value for a character that is represented by a surrogate pair. The character 'ð ®·' has a code point of 134071.

use_cases.title: Comparing `codePointAt()` with `charCodeAt()`
use_cases.code:
const str = 'ð ®·';
console.log(`codePointAt(): ${str.codePointAt(0)}, charCodeAt(): ${str.charCodeAt(0)}`);
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates the difference between `codePointAt()` and `charCodeAt()` for characters that are represented by surrogate pairs. While `codePointAt()` returns the full code point value, `charCodeAt()` only returns the value of the first code unit.

use_cases.title: Using `codePointAt()` with standard characters
use_cases.code:
const str = 'Hello World!';
console.log(str.codePointAt(1));
use_cases.explanation: Shows how `codePointAt()` can also be used to get the code point of standard characters within a string. The character 'e' in 'Hello' has a code point of 101.

description: Joins two or more strings and returns a new joined string.

parameters.description: Required. The strings to be joined.

return.value: A new string containing the concatenated values.

use_cases.title: Concatenating strings
use_cases.explanation: Combines several strings into one. This use case demonstrates the concat method for strings, showcasing how to join multiple string values into a single string, including adding spaces or punctuation.

use_cases.title: Concatenating with variables
use_cases.explanation: Creates a full name from two variables. This illustrates using concat to combine string variables, useful for assembling structured text data from individual components.

use_cases.title: Combining strings and numbers
use_cases.explanation: Joins a string with numeric data and additional text. This example shows concat's ability to work with mixed data types by implicitly converting numbers to strings, facilitating the creation of messages that include dynamic numeric values.

use_cases.title: Using concat in a loop
use_cases.explanation: Accumulates elements of an array into a single string. By iterating over an array and concatenating each element to a base string, this demonstrates how concat can be effectively used in loops for building up a string from array elements.

use_cases.title: Concatenating with empty strings
use_cases.explanation: Shows concat's behavior when used with empty strings or spaces as separators. This use case is useful for understanding how to insert spaces or other separators between strings to maintain readability and structure in the concatenated result.

description: Returns the function that created the String object's prototype.

return.value: The String constructor function that created the object's prototype.

use_cases.title: Identifying string type
use_cases.code:
const greeting = 'Hello, world!';
console.log(greeting.constructor === String);
use_cases.explanation: Checks if the variable `greeting` is an instance of `String`. This use case demonstrates how to use the `constructor` property to verify the type of an object, confirming that `greeting` is indeed a string.

use_cases.title: Creating a new string instance
use_cases.explanation: Uses the `constructor` of `originalString` to create a new `String` instance. This illustrates how the `constructor` property can dynamically instantiate new objects of the same type as the existing object, facilitating the creation of new strings.

use_cases.title: Comparing constructors
use_cases.code:
const text = 'Sample text';
console.log(text.constructor === String);
use_cases.explanation: Compares the `constructor` property of a string object to the `String` global constructor. This confirms that `text` is constructed by the `String` function, highlighting how the `constructor` property can be utilized to distinguish string objects.

description: Checks whether a string ends with specified string/characters.

parameters.description: Required. The string to search for.
Optional. The length of the string to search. Default value is the length of the string.

return.value: True if the string ends with the search value, false otherwise.

use_cases.title: Check string suffix
use_cases.explanation: Determines if the file name ends with the '.pdf' extension. This use case demonstrates endsWith method to verify file types or extensions, showcasing a straightforward approach to string suffix checking.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive check
use_cases.explanation: Checks if the greeting ends with 'world' using a case-sensitive comparison. This illustrates endsWith method's sensitivity to case, emphasizing the importance of matching case in string comparisons.

use_cases.title: Using length parameter
use_cases.explanation: Searches if 'message' ends with 'substring' considering only the first 19 characters. This shows how endsWith can be constrained to a substring by specifying a length, useful for checking ends within a specific context of the string.

use_cases.title: Negative length parameter
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to use a negative length, which is treated as 0, thus always returning false. This underscores the behavior of endsWith when provided with invalid length parameters, highlighting edge cases in string checking.

use_cases.title: Checking endings in an array of strings
use_cases.explanation: Verifies if every file name in an array ends with '.pdf'. By using endsWith in conjunction with Array.prototype.every, this example demonstrates how to collectively check multiple strings for a specific suffix.

description: Converts Unicode values to characters.

parameters.description: Required. One or more Unicode values to be converted.

return.value: A string created from the specified Unicode values.

use_cases.title: Creating characters from codes
use_cases.explanation: Converts character codes 65 ('A') and 66 ('B') into their corresponding characters, forming the string 'AB'. This demonstrates how to use fromCharCode() to translate UTF-16 code units into human-readable characters.

use_cases.title: Generating a string from an array of codes
use_cases.explanation: Creates the string 'Hello' from an array of character codes. By applying fromCharCode() with an array of codes, this illustrates a method for constructing strings from arrays containing multiple character codes.

use_cases.title: Special characters and symbols
use_cases.explanation: Generates a string containing the heart symbol ('â™¥') from its character code (9829). This example shows fromCharCode()'s ability to create strings with special characters and symbols based on their UTF-16 code units.

use_cases.title: Combining letters and numbers
use_cases.explanation: Forms a string '012ABC' by combining the codes for digits and letters. This use case highlights fromCharCode()'s versatility in handling both numeric and alphabetic characters within the same string.

use_cases.title: Decoding message
use_cases.explanation: Decodes an array of character codes into the string 'Secret'. Utilizing the spread operator (...), this demonstrates a modern approach to converting a sequence of character codes into a readable string.

description: Creates a string from the specified sequence of code points. It is a static method of the String object.

parameters.description: One or more Unicode code points. These can be specified as a series of numbers that represent Unicode code points.

return.value: A string consisting of the characters corresponding to the sequence of code points.

use_cases.title: Creating a string from Unicode code points
use_cases.code: console.log(String.fromCodePoint(134071));
use_cases.explanation: This example shows how to create a string from a single Unicode code point. The code point 134071 corresponds to the character 'ð ®·'.

use_cases.title: Combining multiple code points into a string
use_cases.code: console.log(String.fromCodePoint(72, 101, 108, 108, 111));
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates creating a string ('Hello') by specifying the Unicode code points for each character. The code points 72, 101, 108, 108, 111 correspond to 'H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', respectively.

use_cases.title: Using fromCodePoint() with high Unicode values
use_cases.code: console.log(String.fromCodePoint(0x1F600));
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates creating a string containing a character from outside the Basic Multilingual Plane, specifically the 'grinning face' emoji (ðŸ˜€). The example uses the hexadecimal code point 0x1F600.

description: Checks whether a string contains the specified string/characters.

parameters.description: Required. The string to search for.
Optional. The position to start from. Default value is 0.

return.value: True if the search string is found anywhere within the given string, false otherwise.

use_cases.title: Check substring presence
use_cases.explanation: Determines if the sentence contains the substring 'fox'. This use case demonstrates the includes method for performing substring searches within a string, showcasing a straightforward approach to checking for the presence of specific text segments.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive search
use_cases.explanation: Searches for 'hello' in a case-sensitive manner, resulting in false. This illustrates includes method's sensitivity to case, emphasizing the need for matching the case of the substring for a successful search.

use_cases.title: Using position parameter
use_cases.explanation: Searches for 'Nemo' starting from index 5. This shows how includes can be constrained to start searching from a specified position, useful for narrowing down the search area within a large string.

use_cases.title: Substring not found
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to find 'urgent' within the note, which is not present, thus returning false. This use case highlights includes method's return of false when the specified substring cannot be found within the target string.

use_cases.title: Checking for empty string
use_cases.explanation: Confirms that an empty string ('') is considered to be found in any string, returning true. This underscores an edge case where includes method always finds an empty string within another string, demonstrating its default behavior for such searches.

description: Returns the position of the first occurrence of a specified value in a string.

parameters.description: Required. The string to search for.
Optional. The position to start from (default is 0).

return.value: The index of the first occurrence of the search value, or -1 if not found.

use_cases.title: Basic search
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the substring 'world' within the phrase, returning its starting index. This demonstrates the basic use of indexOf() to locate a substring within a string.

use_cases.title: Find first occurrence of a substring
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the substring 'world' within the text and returns its first occurrence index. This demonstrates indexOf's ability to locate a specific substring in a string, providing the starting index where the substring is found.

use_cases.title: Substring not found
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to find 'absent' in the message. Since the substring does not exist, indexOf returns -1, indicating the substring was not found. This highlights indexOf's return value for searches that do not match any part of the string.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive search
use_cases.explanation: Looks for 'javascript' in a case-sensitive manner within 'JavaScript is fun', resulting in -1 since the cases do not match. This illustrates indexOf's case sensitivity in searching for substrings.

use_cases.title: Using start position parameter
use_cases.explanation: Searches for 'repeat' starting from index 10, locating the third occurrence. This shows how the startIndex parameter can be used to skip initial occurrences and find subsequent matches in the string.

use_cases.title: Finding a single character
use_cases.explanation: Locates the index of the character 'j' within the alphabet string. This simple use case demonstrates indexOf's utility for finding the position of individual characters within a string.

description: Returns the position of the last occurrence of a specified value in a string.

parameters.description: Required. The string to search for.
Optional. The position where to start. Default value is string length.

return.value: The index of the last occurrence of the search value, or -1 if not found.

use_cases.title: Basic search for the last occurrence
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the last occurrence of 'world' within the text, ignoring case sensitivity, and returns its starting index. This illustrates the basic use of lastIndexOf() to find the position of a substring, showing how it searches from the end of the string towards the beginning.

use_cases.title: Search with start index
use_cases.explanation: Begins searching for 'hello' backwards from index 15, finding the first occurrence. This example shows how lastIndexOf() works with an optional start index to limit the search to a specific part of the string.

use_cases.title: Substring not found
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to find 'Python' within the message. Since the substring is not present, lastIndexOf() returns -1, indicating the substring was not found in the string.

description: Returns the length of a string.

return.value: The length of the string.

use_cases.title: Determine string length
use_cases.explanation: Calculates the length of the greeting string, including punctuation and spaces. This basic use case demonstrates how to access the length property to determine the number of characters in a string.

use_cases.title: Empty string length
use_cases.explanation: Checks the length of an empty string, which is 0. This illustrates the length property's behavior with an empty string, showing that it accurately reflects the absence of characters.

use_cases.title: Length with special characters
use_cases.explanation: Counts the number of characters in a string containing special characters. This use case highlights that the length property counts each character, including those outside the standard ASCII range, as a single character.

use_cases.title: Length of a string with whitespace
use_cases.explanation: Determines the length of a string comprised only of whitespace characters. This example shows that spaces are counted as characters when calculating a string's length.

use_cases.title: Comparing lengths of two strings
use_cases.explanation: Compares the lengths of two different strings to check if they are the same. This demonstrates using the length property for comparison purposes, useful in scenarios where string length equality might be a criterion.

description: Compares two strings in the current locale.

parameters.description: Required. The string to compare with.

return.value: A number indicating whether the reference string comes before, after, or is the same as the given string in sort order.

use_cases.title: Basic alphabetical comparison
use_cases.explanation: Compares two strings alphabetically in the current locale. Since 'apple' comes before 'banana', the method returns a negative value, indicating that string1 precedes string2 in sort order.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive comparison
use_cases.explanation: Performs a case-sensitive comparison between two strings that differ only in case. Depending on the locale, this may return a positive or negative value, but with the 'case' sensitivity option, it treats the strings as distinct.

use_cases.title: Comparing with accents
use_cases.explanation: Compares two strings where one has an accent and the other does not, using a specific locale ('en') and accent sensitivity. The method returns a non-zero value, indicating the strings are considered different with respect to their accents.

use_cases.title: Numerical string comparison
use_cases.explanation: Compares two numeric strings according to their numeric values when the 'numeric' option is true. '2' is considered greater than '10' in numeric comparison, so the method returns a positive value.

use_cases.title: Same strings comparison
use_cases.explanation: Compares two identical strings. Since the strings are the same, the method returns 0, indicating no difference in sort order between string1 and string2.

description: Searches a string for a match against a regular expression, and returns the matches.

parameters.description: Required. The search value. A regular expression (or a string that will be converted to a regular expression).

return.value: An Array containing the matched results or null if no matches are found.

use_cases.title: Finding a word
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the word 'quick' within the text using a regular expression. This illustrates how match() can be used to find specific words or patterns in a string, returning an array containing the matched word.

use_cases.title: Extracting all digits
use_cases.explanation: Uses a regular expression to find all sequences of digits in the string, demonstrating match()'s capability to extract all matches with the global ('g') flag, resulting in an array of all digit sequences found.

use_cases.title: Capturing groups
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates the use of capturing groups in a regular expression to extract the name and age from a string. match() returns an array where the first element is the full matched string, and subsequent elements are the values captured by the groups.

use_cases.title: No match found
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to find digits in a string that contains none. This example shows that match() returns null when no matches are found, highlighting the need to check the result before accessing array elements.

use_cases.title: Matching with flags
use_cases.explanation: Searches for lines starting with 'S' and ending with 'e' in a multiline string using both global ('g') and multiline ('m') flags. This demonstrates match()'s ability to work with multiline strings and specific pattern flags to refine search criteria.

description: Returns an iterator of all matches of the string against a regular expression, including capturing groups.

parameters.description: A regular expression object. If a non-RegExp object `regexp` is passed, it is implicitly converted to a RegExp with `new RegExp(regexp)`. The regular expression must have the global (`g`) flag set; otherwise, a TypeError will be thrown.

return.value: An iterator that yields objects for each match, with each object containing the matched text, index, input string, and groups array for capturing groups.

use_cases.title: Finding all matches with capturing groups
use_cases.explanation: This example demonstrates how to use `matchAll()` to find all matches of a pattern within a string, including capturing groups. Each match is an array with the full match, followed by the captured groups.

use_cases.title: Extracting multiple groups from a formatted string
use_cases.explanation: Shows how to extract first and last names from a comma-separated string. The `matchAll()` method is used to iterate over each match, capturing and logging first and last names separately.

use_cases.title: Using matchAll() without the global flag throws an error
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates that attempting to use `matchAll()` with a regex without the global (`g`) flag results in a TypeError, emphasizing the requirement for the `g` flag in the regex.

description: Returns the Unicode Normalization Form of the string, transforming it to a standardized representation.

parameters.description: The Unicode Normalization Form to use. Can be one of 'NFC' (Normalization Form Canonical Composition, default), 'NFD' (Normalization Form Canonical Decomposition), 'NFKC' (Normalization Form Compatibility Composition), or 'NFKD' (Normalization Form Compatibility Decomposition).

return.value: A new string representing the normalized form of the original string.

use_cases.title: Normalizing a string with combining characters
use_cases.explanation: This example shows how to normalize a string that contains a letter and a combining character into a single precomposed character, if possible, using the 'NFC' form.

use_cases.title: Comparing normalized strings for equality
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates the importance of normalizing strings before comparing them for equality, especially when dealing with diacritics and other special characters.

use_cases.title: Exploring different normalization forms
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates the differences between the four normalization forms by normalizing a string that can be represented in multiple ways, showing how each form affects the resultant string.

description: Pads the current string from the end with another string until a certain length is reached. The method ensures the resulting string reaches a given length by appending the pad string to the end of the original string.

parameters.description: The length of the resulting string once the current string has been padded. If the value is less than the string's current length, no padding is applied.
The string to append to the current string. If this string is too long to stay within the target length, it will be truncated. The default value is a space (' ').

return.value: A new string that has been padded from the end with the given padString until the targetLength is reached.

use_cases.title: Ensuring a string reaches a specific length
use_cases.code: 'Example'.padEnd(10, '.')
use_cases.explanation: Results in 'Example...'. This example shows how to use `padEnd()` to extend the length of a string to 10 characters by appending periods.

use_cases.title: Using default padding with spaces
use_cases.code: 'Text'.padEnd(10)
use_cases.explanation: Results in 'Text      '. Demonstrates the use of the default padding (spaces) to extend a string to a specified length when no padString is provided.

use_cases.title: Formatting table output
use_cases.code: ['ID', 'Name', 'Result'].map(text => text.padEnd(15)).join('|')
use_cases.explanation: Results in 'ID            |Name          |Result        '. Illustrates how `padEnd()` can be used to format strings for aligned output in a text-based table.

use_cases.title: Padding with a longer string than needed
use_cases.explanation: Results in 'Short12345'. Shows that if the padString is longer than necessary to reach the target length, it will be truncated to fit the required length.

description: Pads the current string from the start with another string until a certain length is reached.

parameters.description: The length of the resulting string once the current string has been padded. If the value is less than the string's length, the padding will not be applied.
The string to pad the current string with. If this string is too long to stay within the target length, it will be truncated. The default value is a space (' ').

return.value: A new string that has been padded from the start with the given padString until the targetLength is reached.

use_cases.title: Padding a number for display
use_cases.code: '5'.padStart(3, '0')
use_cases.explanation: Results in '005'. This example demonstrates padding a numeric string with leading zeros to ensure it has a length of 3 characters, commonly used in displaying numbers with a fixed width.

use_cases.title: Formatting a part of a date
use_cases.code: '1'.padStart(2, '0')
use_cases.explanation: Results in '01'. This use case shows how to format date components (like month or day) to ensure they are always displayed with two digits.

use_cases.title: Using default padding
use_cases.code: 'hello'.padStart(10)
use_cases.explanation: Results in '     hello'. This example illustrates the use of the default padding with spaces to make a string reach a certain length.

use_cases.title: Padding with a longer string
use_cases.explanation: Results in '1234567abc'. It shows that when the padString is longer than needed to reach the targetLength, it is truncated to fit exactly.

description: Returns the raw string form of a template literal. This method allows for the creation of strings that include backslashes without interpreting them as escape characters.

parameters.description: An object resembling the `template` object that is passed to a tag function in a tagged template literal. It contains `raw` property, which stores an array of string literals.
Comma-separated values that should replace the placeholders in the template.

return.value: A string where the escape sequences are not processed, but are instead left as is.

use_cases.title: Creating a path string on Windows
use_cases.code: console.log(String.raw`C:\Development\profile\aboutme.html`);
use_cases.explanation: This example demonstrates using `String.raw()` to create a file path string on Windows, where the backslash (`\`) is used as a directory separator. The raw method ensures that backslashes are treated literally, rather than as escape characters.

use_cases.title: Using substitutions in raw strings
use_cases.code:
const name = 'world';
console.log(String.raw`Hello, \${name}!`);
use_cases.explanation: Shows how `String.raw()` can be used with substitutions, where the substitution is included in the resulting string without processing the backslash as an escape character.

use_cases.title: Escaping characters in regular expressions
use_cases.code:
const regex = String.raw`\d+`;
console.log(`The regex is: ${regex}`);
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates the use of `String.raw()` for defining a regular expression pattern as a string, where double backslashes are used to denote a single backslash in the regex pattern (`\d+` matches one or more digits).

description: Returns a new string with a specified number of copies of an existing string.

parameters.description: Required. The number of times to repeat the string.

return.value: A new string containing the specified number of copies of the original string.

use_cases.title: Repeating a string multiple times
use_cases.explanation: Creates a new string by repeating 'na ' five times, illustrating how repeat() can be used to duplicate a string fragment multiple times, useful for generating patterns or repeated content.

use_cases.title: Zero times repetition
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates that calling repeat() with 0 returns an empty string. This is useful for cases where the repetition amount might be dynamically determined, ensuring that no error occurs when the repeat count is zero.

use_cases.title: Creating a separator line
use_cases.code:
const separator = '-'.repeat(10); 
console.log(separator);
use_cases.explanation: Uses repeat() to create a string consisting of ten dashes, showcasing a practical use for generating simple text-based separators or dividers in console output or UI components.

use_cases.title: Formatting console output
use_cases.explanation: Pads a title string to a fixed length by appending spaces, demonstrating repeat()'s utility in text formatting, particularly for aligning or padding strings in console output or text-based UIs.

use_cases.title: Building a simple ASCII art
use_cases.explanation: Generates a simple ASCII art representation of stairs by repeating a pattern of spaces followed by an asterisk and a newline. This example highlights repeat()'s application in creative contexts, such as generating ASCII art or text-based designs.

description: Searches a string for a specified value, or a regular expression, and returns a new string where the specified values are replaced.

parameters.description: Required. The value, or regular expression, that will be searched for in the string.
Required. The value to replace the specified value/regular expression with.

return.value: A new string with the specified value(s) replaced.

use_cases.title: Replacing a substring
use_cases.explanation: Substitutes 'fox' with 'cat' in the given sentence. This demonstrates how replace() can be used to change specific substrings within a string, showcasing a basic text replacement operation.

use_cases.title: Global replacement with RegExp
use_cases.explanation: Uses a regular expression with the global flag ('g') to replace all occurrences of 'cat' with 'squirrel'. This illustrates replace()'s ability to perform global replacements across the entire string, not just the first match.

use_cases.title: Case-insensitive replacement
use_cases.explanation: Performs a case-insensitive replacement, turning 'Excellent' into 'good'. By using the case-insensitive flag ('i') in the regular expression, this example demonstrates how to match and replace strings regardless of their case.

use_cases.title: Replacing with a function
use_cases.explanation: Replaces the first sequence of digits with asterisks, with the number of asterisks equal to the length of the matched digits. This use of a replacement function allows for dynamic replacements based on the content of the match.

use_cases.title: Swapping words
use_cases.explanation: Swaps the order of two words using capturing groups and references in the replacement string. This showcases replace()'s capability to reorganize text segments dynamically using pattern matching and replacement references.

description: Replaces all occurrences of a specified value, or a regular expression, with a new value.

parameters.description: Required. The value, or regular expression, to search for.
Required. The new value to replace with. This parameter can be a JavaScript function.

return.value: A new string with all occurrences of the specified value replaced.

use_cases.title: Global string replacement
use_cases.explanation: Replaces all occurrences of 'dog' with 'fox' in the paragraph. This demonstrates how replaceAll() can be used to perform a global replacement without needing a regular expression with a global flag.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive replacement
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to replace 'good' with 'great', but due to case sensitivity, no changes are made. This highlights replaceAll()'s case-sensitive nature and the importance of matching cases for successful replacements.

use_cases.title: Using regular expression without global flag
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to use replaceAll() with a regular expression without the global ('g') flag, resulting in an error. This example is intended to show that replaceAll() with a regular expression requires the 'g' flag for it to work.

use_cases.title: Replacing special characters
use_cases.explanation: Converts Windows-style file path separators to web-friendly forward slashes. This use case demonstrates replaceAll()'s utility in modifying strings containing special characters or patterns that require global replacement.

use_cases.title: Dynamically generated replacement string
use_cases.explanation: Replaces a specific keyword ('Spoiler:') with a '[CENSORED]' tag throughout the text. This illustrates how replaceAll() can be used to dynamically alter or redact parts of a string based on content-specific criteria.

description: Searches a string for a specified value, or regular expression, and returns the position of the match.

parameters.description: Required. The search value. A regular expression (or a string that will be converted to a regular expression).

return.value: The index of the first match between the regular expression and the given string, or -1 if no match was found.

use_cases.title: Basic search with literal string
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the term 'needle' within the text and returns its starting index. This demonstrates how search() can be used with a simple string argument to locate the position of a substring within a larger string.

use_cases.title: Search with regular expression
use_cases.explanation: Uses a regular expression to find the position of a price pattern within the string. This example illustrates search()'s capability to work with regular expressions for more complex pattern matching.

use_cases.title: Case-insensitive search
use_cases.explanation: Performs a case-insensitive search for 'JavaScript' using a regular expression with the 'i' flag. This showcases how search() can be adapted to ignore case differences in pattern matching.

use_cases.title: Search for a non-existing pattern
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to locate a numeric pattern in a text devoid of numbers, resulting in -1. This indicates that search() returns -1 when the specified pattern cannot be found, useful for conditional checks in string processing.

use_cases.title: Finding special characters
use_cases.explanation: Searches for the first occurrence of several special characters using a character set in a regular expression. This example highlights search()'s utility in identifying specific characters within a string, demonstrating its effectiveness with character classes.

description: Extracts a part of a string and returns a new string.

parameters.description: Required. The start position. (First character is 0).
Optional. The end position (up to, but not including). Default is the length of the string.

return.value: A new string containing the extracted section of the string.

use_cases.title: Extracting a substring
use_cases.explanation: Extracts the substring 'quick' from the sentence. This use case demonstrates slice() for selecting a specific portion of a string based on start and end indices, showcasing its basic utility in substring extraction.

use_cases.title: Using negative indices
use_cases.explanation: Extracts 'Firefox' from the text using a negative start index. This illustrates slice()'s ability to handle negative indices, counting from the end of the string to easily extract substrings without calculating their exact positions.

use_cases.title: Omitting end index
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the file name 'report.txt' by specifying only the start index. This example shows how omitting the end index in slice() will extract the substring from the start position to the end of the string.

use_cases.title: Extracting entire string
use_cases.explanation: Creates a copy of the entire string by not specifying start or end indices. This demonstrates slice()'s flexibility, allowing for the entire string to be copied when no indices are provided.

use_cases.title: Handling out-of-range indices
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to slice the string from index 5 to an out-of-range end index, returning 'string'. This highlights slice()'s behavior when the end index exceeds the string's length, effectively treating it as the string's end.

description: Splits a string into an array of substrings.

parameters.description: Optional. A string or regular expression to use for splitting. If omitted, an array with the original string is returned.
Optional. An integer that limits the number of splits. Items after the limit are not included in the array.

return.value: An array of strings, split at each point where the separator occurs in the given string.

use_cases.title: Splitting a sentence into words
use_cases.explanation: Divides a sentence into an array of words using a space (' ') as the delimiter. This illustrates split()'s basic usage for breaking down strings into manageable parts, ideal for text processing and analysis.

use_cases.title: Using a limit parameter
use_cases.explanation: Splits the string into an array of the first three elements based on the comma delimiter, demonstrating how the limit parameter controls the number of split elements returned.

use_cases.title: Splitting with regular expression
use_cases.explanation: Uses a regular expression as the delimiter to split the string by multiple types of punctuation and spaces. This showcases split()'s flexibility in handling complex string patterns, making it powerful for parsing varied text formats.

use_cases.title: Empty string as delimiter
use_cases.explanation: Breaks down a word into its individual characters by using an empty string ('') as the delimiter. This example highlights split()'s ability to dissect strings into arrays of single characters, useful for character-level operations.

use_cases.title: No delimiter specified
use_cases.explanation: Without specifying a delimiter, split() returns an array containing the original string as its sole element. This demonstrates split()'s default behavior when no delimiter is provided, effectively not splitting the string.

description: Checks whether a string starts with specified string/characters.

parameters.description: Required. The string to search for.
Optional. The position at which to start the search. Default is 0.

return.value: True if the string starts with the search value, false otherwise.

use_cases.title: Checking string prefix
use_cases.explanation: Determines if the sentence starts with the word 'The'. This basic use case demonstrates startsWith()'s functionality for checking if a string begins with a specified substring, showcasing its utility in conditional logic based on string content.

use_cases.title: Case-sensitive comparison
use_cases.explanation: Checks if 'greeting' starts with 'hello', which it does not due to case sensitivity. This highlights startsWith()'s case-sensitive behavior, emphasizing the need for case matching in successful substring comparisons.

use_cases.title: Using position parameter
use_cases.explanation: Searches if 'text' starts with 'event' at position 11. By specifying a start position, this example shows how startsWith() can check for the presence of a substring starting from a specific point within the string.

use_cases.title: Substring not found at start
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to find 'prefix' at the start of the message. Since the substring does not match the beginning of the string, startsWith() returns false, demonstrating its strict requirement for matching at the specified starting position.

use_cases.title: Negative position parameter
use_cases.explanation: Tries to use a negative start position, which JavaScript treats as 0. This indicates that startsWith(), when given a negative position, defaults to starting the search from the beginning of the string.

description: Extracts the characters from a string, beginning at a specified start position, and through the specified number of character.

parameters.description: Required. The start position. First character is at index 0. If start is greater than the string's length, substr() returns an empty string. If start is negative, substr() counts from the end of the string.
Optional. The number of characters to extract. If omitted, it extracts the rest of the string.

return.value: A new string containing the specified part of the given string.

use_cases.title: Extracting a substring
use_cases.explanation: Extracts 'Firefox' from the string using substr(), starting at index 7 and spanning 7 characters. This demonstrates substr()'s basic usage for extracting a substring from a specific position.

use_cases.title: Using a negative start index
use_cases.explanation: Extracts 'world' by specifying a negative start index, counting back from the end of the string. This illustrates how substr() handles negative indices to start the extraction from the end.

use_cases.title: Omitting length parameter
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the substring starting from index 7 to the end of the string, as the length parameter is omitted. This shows substr()'s behavior when only the start index is provided, extracting the rest of the string from that point.

use_cases.title: Extracting entire string with positive index
use_cases.explanation: Copies the entire string by starting at index 0 without specifying the length. This demonstrates how to use substr() to make a full copy of the string when starting from the beginning.

use_cases.title: Handling out-of-range start index
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to extract a substring starting well beyond the string's length, resulting in an empty string. This highlights substr()'s return value when the start index exceeds the string's length.

description: Extracts the characters from a string, between two specified indices.

parameters.description: Required. Start position. First character is at index 0.
Optional. End position (up to, but not including). If omitted, extracts to the end of the string.

return.value: A new string containing the extracted characters.

use_cases.title: Extracting a substring
use_cases.explanation: Extracts 'Firefox' from the string by specifying the start index (7) and the end index (14). This demonstrates substring()'s basic usage for extracting a specific portion of a string based on index positions.

use_cases.title: Using indices in reverse order
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the substring 'world' even when the start and end indices are provided in reverse order. This illustrates substring()'s ability to interpret the lower index as the start and the higher as the end, regardless of their order in arguments.

use_cases.title: Omitting the end index
use_cases.explanation: Extracts a directory path from a full file path by specifying only the start index, omitting the end index. This shows substring()'s behavior when the end index is omitted, extracting the substring from the start index to the end of the string.

use_cases.title: Negative start index
use_cases.explanation: Treats a negative start index as 0, resulting in the entire string being returned. This demonstrates how substring() handles negative indices, providing a forgiving mechanism for string extraction.

use_cases.title: Extracting from start to a specific character
use_cases.explanation: Retrieves the username from an email address by extracting the substring from the start to the character '@'. This use case highlights substring()'s utility in parsing and extracting specific data from a string based on dynamic conditions.

description: Converts a string to lowercase letters, according to the host's current locale.

return.value: The calling string value converted to lower case, according to any locale-specific case mappings.

use_cases.title: Basic conversion to lowercase
use_cases.explanation: Converts the entire string to lowercase according to the host's current locale. This demonstrates toLocaleLowerCase()'s basic usage for making strings uniformly lowercase, useful for case-insensitive comparisons or text normalization.

use_cases.title: Locale-specific case conversion
use_cases.explanation: Applies locale-specific rules for the German language to convert 'StraÃŸe' to lowercase. This highlights toLocaleLowerCase()'s ability to handle language-specific casing rules, such as the 'ÃŸ' character in German.

use_cases.title: Comparison without locale
use_cases.explanation: Converts 'Ä°' (dotless I) to its lowercase equivalent in Turkish, which respects the locale-specific behavior of the Turkish language, differentiating it from the general conversion behavior seen in languages like English.

use_cases.title: Handling mixed-language text
use_cases.explanation: Converts a mixed-language string to lowercase using the Turkish locale, demonstrating toLocaleLowerCase()'s effectiveness across different alphabets and language rules within a single operation.

use_cases.title: Case conversion without affecting numbers
use_cases.explanation: Converts letters to lowercase without altering the numbers in a string containing both alphabetic and numeric characters. This example shows that toLocaleLowerCase() selectively applies case conversion to letters, leaving non-alphabetic characters unaffected.

description: Converts a string to uppercase letters, according to the host's current locale.

return.value: The calling string value converted to upper case, according to any locale-specific case mappings.

use_cases.title: Basic conversion to uppercase
use_cases.explanation: Converts the entire string to uppercase according to the host's current locale. This demonstrates toLocaleUpperCase()'s basic usage for making strings uniformly uppercase, useful for formatting or creating visually consistent text output.

use_cases.title: Locale-specific case conversion
use_cases.explanation: Applies locale-specific rules for the Turkish language to correctly convert 'i' to 'Ä°' and 'ÄŸ' to 'Äž'. This highlights toLocaleUpperCase()'s ability to handle language-specific casing rules, particularly for languages where uppercase transformations differ from the default locale.

use_cases.title: Comparison without locale
use_cases.explanation: Converts 'istanbul' to uppercase using the English (United States) locale. This illustrates how using a specific locale can affect the conversion result, especially for languages with unique uppercase rules.

use_cases.title: Handling mixed-language text
use_cases.explanation: Converts a mixed-language string to uppercase using the Turkish locale, demonstrating toLocaleUpperCase()'s effectiveness across different alphabets and language rules within a single operation.

use_cases.title: Case conversion without affecting numbers
use_cases.explanation: Converts letters to uppercase without altering the numbers in a string containing both alphabetic and numeric characters. This example shows that toLocaleUpperCase() selectively applies case conversion to letters, leaving non-alphabetic characters unaffected.

description: Converts a string to lowercase letters.

return.value: The calling string value converted to lower case.

use_cases.title: Basic conversion to lowercase
use_cases.explanation: Converts the entire statement to lowercase. This use case illustrates `toLowerCase()`'s basic functionality for transforming all uppercase letters in a string to their lowercase counterparts, useful for normalization or case-insensitive comparisons.

use_cases.title: No effect on numbers or special characters
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates that `toLowerCase()` affects only alphabetic characters, leaving numbers, spaces, and special characters unchanged. This is useful for case conversion operations where non-alphabetic characters are present.

use_cases.title: Lowercasing a mixed-case string
use_cases.explanation: Normalizes a string with mixed uppercase and lowercase letters to all lowercase. This example shows `toLowerCase()`'s utility in standardizing text input, such as user-generated content or programming identifiers.

use_cases.title: Comparing strings case-insensitively
use_cases.explanation: Uses `toLowerCase()` to compare two strings regardless of their original case, resulting in a case-insensitive comparison. This technique is commonly employed in search and matching algorithms where case variations should not affect the outcome.

use_cases.title: Effect on international characters
use_cases.explanation: Shows `toLowerCase()` applied to a string containing an international character with a dot ('Ä°'). Depending on the locale and environment, results may vary, illustrating the method's limitations with non-ASCII characters and the potential need for locale-aware transformations.

description: Returns a string representing the specified object.

return.value: A string representing the object.

use_cases.title: Converting a number to a string
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates converting a numeric value to a string using `toString()`. This is a basic usage scenario where `toString()` is applied to a number, highlighting its utility in type conversion for formatting or concatenation purposes.

use_cases.title: String representation of an array
use_cases.explanation: Converts an array to a comma-separated string representation. This example shows `toString()` being used on an array, illustrating how it can convert complex data structures into readable string formats.

use_cases.title: Using toString on a boolean
use_cases.explanation: Transforms a boolean value into its string representation ('true' or 'false'). This demonstrates `toString()`'s versatility across different data types, making it suitable for boolean values' textual representation.

use_cases.title: Custom object toString override
use_cases.explanation: Shows how to override the `toString()` method in a custom object to return a meaningful string representation. This example illustrates enhancing readability and information content of object string representations through custom `toString()` implementations.

use_cases.title: Converting undefined and null
use_cases.explanation: Attempts to call `toString()` on `undefined` and `null` values, which leads to a runtime error. This highlights a limitation of `toString()`, as calling it directly on `undefined` or `null` is not allowed and requires careful handling or prior checking.

description: Converts a string to uppercase letters.

return.value: The calling string value converted to upper case.

use_cases.title: Basic conversion to uppercase
use_cases.explanation: Converts the entire sentence to uppercase. This demonstrates `toUpperCase()`'s basic functionality for transforming all lowercase letters in a string to their uppercase counterparts, useful for formatting or creating visually consistent text output.

use_cases.title: No effect on numbers or special characters
use_cases.explanation: Shows that `toUpperCase()` affects only alphabetic characters, leaving numbers, spaces, and special characters unchanged. This is useful for case conversion operations where non-alphabetic characters are present.

use_cases.title: Uppercasing a mixed-case string
use_cases.explanation: Normalizes a string with mixed uppercase and lowercase letters to all uppercase. This example shows `toUpperCase()`'s utility in standardizing text input, such as user-generated content or programming identifiers.

use_cases.title: Comparing strings case-insensitively
use_cases.explanation: Uses `toUpperCase()` to compare two strings regardless of their original case, resulting in a case-insensitive comparison. This technique is commonly employed in search and matching algorithms where case variations should not affect the outcome.

use_cases.title: Effect on international characters
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates `toUpperCase()` applied to a string containing international characters, such as the Turkish dotted 'i' ('iÌ‡'), and its conversion to uppercase. Depending on the environment, this can show how `toUpperCase()` handles locale-specific characters.

description: Removes whitespace from both ends of a string.

return.value: A new string representing the calling string stripped of whitespace from both ends.

use_cases.title: Removing whitespace from both ends
use_cases.explanation: Trims leading and trailing whitespace from a string. This use case demonstrates `trim()`'s basic functionality for cleaning up user input or other strings where extra spaces at the beginning or end are undesirable.

use_cases.title: Trimming does not affect inner spaces
use_cases.explanation: Shows that `trim()` removes spaces only from the start and end of the string, without altering spaces between words. This is important for maintaining the integrity of the original text while still performing basic cleanup.

use_cases.title: No change on strings without extra spaces
use_cases.explanation: Applies `trim()` to a string that doesn't have leading or trailing whitespace, demonstrating that it leaves such strings unchanged. This illustrates `trim()`'s non-destructive nature when no trimming is necessary.

use_cases.title: Trimming strings with newline characters
use_cases.explanation: Removes newline characters along with spaces from the beginning and end of a multiline string. This highlights `trim()`'s capability to handle various types of whitespace characters, not just spaces.

use_cases.title: Using trim on an empty string
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates that applying `trim()` to a string consisting only of spaces results in an empty string. This use case shows `trim()`'s effectiveness in clearing strings that are whitespace only.

description: Removes whitespace from the end of a string.

return.value: A new string representing the calling string stripped of whitespace from its end.

use_cases.title: Removing trailing whitespace
use_cases.explanation: Trims the trailing spaces from the string, leaving the leading and internal spaces unaffected. This demonstrates `trimEnd()`'s functionality for cleaning up strings that have unnecessary whitespace at the end.

use_cases.title: TrimEnd does not affect leading spaces
use_cases.explanation: Shows that `trimEnd()` selectively removes whitespace from the end of a string without altering leading whitespace. This is crucial for scenarios where the integrity of the leading spaces is important.

use_cases.title: Trimming newline characters at the end
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates `trimEnd()`'s ability to remove trailing newline characters along with spaces, useful for processing text input or data where newline characters at the end are not desired.

use_cases.title: No change on strings without trailing spaces
use_cases.explanation: Applies `trimEnd()` to a string that has no trailing whitespace, showing that it leaves such strings unchanged. This underlines `trimEnd()`'s non-destructive behavior when there's nothing to trim at the end.

use_cases.title: Trimming strings with various trailing whitespace
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates removing a mix of trailing spaces, tabs, and newline characters. This use case highlights `trimEnd()`'s versatility in dealing with different types of whitespace characters, ensuring a clean end to the string.

description: Removes whitespace from the beginning of a string.

return.value: A new string representing the calling string stripped of whitespace from its beginning.

use_cases.title: Removing leading whitespace
use_cases.explanation: Trims the leading spaces from the string, leaving the trailing and internal spaces unaffected. This demonstrates `trimStart()`'s functionality for cleaning up strings that have unnecessary whitespace at the beginning.

use_cases.title: TrimStart does not affect trailing spaces
use_cases.explanation: Shows that `trimStart()` selectively removes whitespace from the start of a string without altering trailing whitespace. This is crucial for scenarios where the integrity of the trailing spaces is important.

use_cases.title: Trimming newline characters at the start
use_cases.explanation: Illustrates `trimStart()`'s ability to remove leading newline characters along with spaces, useful for processing text input or data where newline characters at the start are not desired.

use_cases.title: No change on strings without leading spaces
use_cases.explanation: Applies `trimStart()` to a string that has no leading whitespace, showing that it leaves such strings unchanged. This underlines `trimStart()`'s non-destructive behavior when there's nothing to trim at the beginning.

use_cases.title: Trimming strings with various leading whitespace
use_cases.explanation: Demonstrates removing a mix of leading spaces, tabs, and newline characters. This use case highlights `trimStart()`'s versatility in dealing with different types of whitespace characters, ensuring a clean start to the string.

description: Returns the primitive value of a String object.

return.value: The primitive value of the specified String object.

use_cases.title: Getting primitive value from a String object
use_cases.explanation: Creates a String object and then uses `valueOf()` to obtain its primitive string value. This example illustrates the basic use of `valueOf()` to convert a String object back into a primitive string for direct manipulation or comparison.

use_cases.title: Comparison between String object and primitive string
use_cases.explanation: Compares a String object with a primitive string using `valueOf()`. This demonstrates how `valueOf()` is essential for comparing the content of a String object with a primitive string, ensuring accurate comparisons by converting the object to its primitive form.

use_cases.title: Implicit use of valueOf in concatenation
use_cases.explanation: Shows an implicit call to `valueOf()` during string concatenation. JavaScript automatically converts the String object to a primitive string when it is concatenated with another primitive string, demonstrating an implicit use of `valueOf()` in operations.

use_cases.title: Using valueOf with template literals
use_cases.explanation: Utilizes `valueOf()` to embed a String object's value within a template literal. This highlights the method's utility in ensuring that the object's primitive value is used in contexts that require string interpolation or embedding.

use_cases.title: Implicit and explicit valueOf comparison
use_cases.explanation: Compares implicit and explicit uses of `valueOf()` in equating a String object to a primitive string. Both approaches demonstrate how JavaScript handles the conversion of String objects to their primitive counterpart for accurate string comparisons.
